What a change was wrought in the hearts of the disciples, as they looked once more on the loved countenance of their Master! [Luke 24:27.] In a more complete and perfect sense than 
350
ever before, they had \93found him, of whom Moses in the law, and the prophets, did write.\94 The uncertainty, the anguish, the despair, gave place to perfect assurance, to unclouded faith. What marvel that after his ascension they \93were continually in the temple, praising and blessing God.\94 The people, knowing only of the Saviour's ignominious death, looked to see in their faces the expression of sorrow, confusion, and defeat; but they saw there gladness and triumph. What a preparation these disciples had received for the work before them! They had passed through the deepest trial which it was possible for them to experience, and had seen how, when to human vision all was lost, the word of God had been triumphantly accomplished. Henceforward what could daunt their faith, or chill the ardor of their love? In the keenest sorrow they had \93strong consolation,\94 a hope which was as \93an anchor of the soul, both sure and steadfast.\94 [Hebrews 6:18, 19.] They had been witness to the wisdom and power of God, and they were \93persuaded, that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor principalities, nor powers, nor things present, nor things to come, nor height, nor depth, nor any other creature\94 would be able to separate them from \93the love of God, which is in Christ Jesus our Lord.\94 \93In all these things,\94 they said, \93we are more than conquerors through Him that loved us.\94 [Romans 8:38, 39, 37.] \93The Word of the Lord endureth forever.\94 [1 Peter 1:25.] And \93who is he that condemneth? It is Christ that died, yea rather, that is risen again, who is even at the right hand of God, who also maketh intercession for us.\94 [Romans 8:34.]
